title: 115_hr868
content: The Act establishes the National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture, defining key terms like Board of Regents, Council, Museum, and Secretary. The National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture is established within the Smithsonian Institution. Its purpose includes collecting, studying, and creating exhibits on Asian Pacific American life, art, history, and culture, as well as collaborating with other institutions. The curr_chunk focuses on collaboration between institutions, historical societies, and educational organizations to promote the study and appreciation of Asian Pacific American life, art, history, and culture. This collaboration includes developing cooperative programs and exhibitions, managing collections, and training museum professionals. The curr_chunk focuses on the establishment of a council to oversee collaborative efforts in promoting the study and appreciation of Asian Pacific American life, art, history, and culture. The National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Council is established within the Smithsonian Institution to oversee the planning, operation, and preservation of the Museum. It advises on budgets, acquisitions, and displays related to Asian Pacific American life, art, history, and culture. The National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Council has the authority to acquire artifacts for the Museum's collections, dispose of items with funds going back to the Museum, and set criteria for the use of collections and resources. The National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Council is responsible for policies on programming, education, exhibitions, and research. The Council also has the authority to preserve, restore, and maintain collections, as well as solicit and accept gifts for the Museum's work. It is composed of 19 voting members, including the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. The National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Council consists of 19 voting members, including the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution and individuals appointed by the Board of Regents based on recommendations from organizations and the Council. Initial appointments must be made within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Council appoints members for 3-year terms, with initial appointees serving staggered terms of 1, 2, or 3 years. Members may be reappointed for a maximum of 2 terms. The National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Council appoints members for 3-year terms, with initial appointees serving staggered terms of 1, 2, or 3 years. Members may be reappointed for a maximum of 2 terms. Vacancies on the Council do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay, except as provided in specific circumstances. The National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Council members serve without pay but are allowed travel expenses. The Council elects a chairperson by majority vote and meets at least twice a year. The Council must meet at least 4 times for its duties under this Act. A majority of voting members constitutes a quorum for conducting business. The Museum will have a Director appointed by the Secretary, who will manage it under the Board of Regents' policies. The Secretary can appoint two additional employees without following standard appointment procedures. These employees may be paid without adhering to certain provisions of the United States Code. Additionally, there are educational and liaison programs outlined in the Act. The Director of the Museum may conduct educational and liaison programs supporting the Museum's goals, including programs on Asian Pacific American life, art, history, and culture using various technologies and in collaboration with schools. The Director will consult with the Institute of Museum and Library Services on grants. The Director of the Institute of Museum and Library Services, in consultation with the Council and the Museum Director, will establish grant and scholarship programs to improve operations, care of collections, provide internship opportunities, and support individuals pursuing studies in Asian Pacific American life, art, history, and culture. SEC. 7. Building for the National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture. The Board of Regents, in consultation with various agencies, must designate a site for the Museum within 12 months of the Act's enactment. If the site is under a Federal agency's jurisdiction, it must be transferred to the Smithsonian Institution. The Board of Regents must consult with various agencies, including the National Capital Planning Commission, the Commission on Fine Arts, and congressional committees, in carrying out its duties related to the Museum site designation. The Board of Regents, in consultation with the Council, may plan, design, and construct a building for the Museum at the designated site. Chapter 89 of title 40, United States, provisions relating to monuments and commemorative works, do not apply. The Board of Regents will share the costs of the Museum project, with 50% from Federal funds and 50% from non-Federal sources. The Council and Board of Regents will consider reports and plans from the National Museum of Asian Pacific American History and Culture Plan for Action Presidential Commission.
